text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for review the new blue album
good to be home this is the latest
full-length LP from underground West
Coast MC blue he's got a few really good
projects under his belt especially the
ones where he collaborated with rapper
and producer exile like smell my flowers
and below the heavens
give me my flowers give me my flowers
there was the LP he put out a handful of
years ago no York which was a bit of a
botched release from Warner Brothers
Records when he signed with them it's an
LP that's decent it's really trippy it's
West Coasters Flying Lotus production on
this album blues bars and delivery are
much more chill and toned down ever
since that album blues output to me has
been really really hit or miss with all
these one-off solo projects that are
maybe a little low fire kind of demo
quality or collaborations that didn't
really seem to escalate his name any
further than I already had been
escalated I just feel like that a lot of
his stuff lately hasn't really been that
stunning or ambitious so of course I was
incredibly indescribably excited when I
first heard that he's going to be coming
out with a new LP right here with a
producer with a one producer working
with one producer for the whole thing
meaning that possibly this record will
be focused and then on top of all of
that this album was also going to be a
double album which in the music world is
basically the mark of ambition but I did
not come out lovin this thing in my
opinion among other things this record
really is overly long either because
there's just straight filler on it or
they're just a lot of songs that pale in
comparison to others and just don't keep
the heat don't keep the momentum of the
album up mostly because of the
production the production on this LP
gets so distorted gets so muffled that
the vocals kind of get lost in the bass
the highs the treble of these songs
doesn't really translate all the time or
it just impedes on the overall quality
of the song there are tracks on here
like the West and the 50s for example
which to me because of the week
recording don't really sound like
anything other than
see a stick demos I actually was not
able to begin enjoying this LP to the
slight degree that I do until I threw it
on headphones basically eliminating all
the really bad bass mixing and mastering
just really finding a way to make the
flaws on this record less audible and
don't get me wrong I love fuzzy warm
slightly lo-fi left-field hip-hop it's
why I love producers like Madlib and J
Dilla Madlib just came out with a record
this year with Freddie Gibbs that is
amazing but right there on pinata that's
like where the low Phi line is is drawn
for me go any further down that road and
Freddie Gibbs lyrics on pinata are
basically inaudible and good to be home
just doesn't step over this line it
Rockets past it like it's a finish line
overall while I do enjoy the composition
of these instrumentals I think we've got
some really great jazz and soul sampling
throughout this LP there's some good
keyboard leads here and there the vibe
and the groove of drums and the rhythms
on these instrumentals are pretty good
as well but it sounds like Bombay had no
other choice than to take these beats
and in order to carry them from where he
produced them to the studio to record
them with blue he had to put them on the
dustiest crappiest most warped cassette
tape in all of California the lyrical
side of this album is really the winner
here and there we get a lot of
braggadocio some personal looks at Blues
past and present and a bit of a tribute
to the West Coast there are a lot of
West Coast emcees and artists featured
in the track listing of this LP there
are also a lot of references to places
in California as well as culture and
artists that came out of there like dr.
Dre ice-t Ice Cube and the list does not
stop there and even the final bonus
track on the first disc of this thing
which I wish came earlier actually as a
bit of a G Funk vibe in the instrumental
to me to me to me to me lyrically the
most interesting track on this entire LP
is the return a song where Blu is
rapping by himself and he's essentially
rapping about his past talking
specifically about his name how he was
given this nickname he came up with it
despite the fact that there were Crips
and just people in general asking why
his name is blue
was there any kind of gang affiliation
so on and so forth saying that he never
gangbang and talking about how he stuck
with that name despite all the drama
around it and how he loves roots from
and so on and so forth
it's a beautiful tribute and it's one of
the few moments on the cell P where I
think the instrumental is great in the
low five production really works in
favor of the weeping horns and strings
then you have Posse tracks on here like
boys in the hood which features a
relentless verse after verse after verse
from West Coast rapper Fushan among
others and everybody is pretty much
rapping about growing up as kids
respectively talking about Saturday
morning cartoons there being parents who
are also addicts and for the most parts
really the tracks that have the most
emcees on them like three or more that
are consistently the most exciting
they're typically really no BS and just
really get down to business
plus with people on here like alchemists
and evidence and prodigy POC dibs on
here Imani from far side is on this
record as well this LP really is kind of
bloated with features I would actually
say a lot of them sound kind of phoned
in but at least the feature list does
give the listener quite a bit to look
forward to not not every verses fire
though that cost verse at the end of
whipped cream is a complete mess the
second disc on this LP the second half
of this LP is a little better there are
a few beats here and there that are
clearer than others on the first disc
and I think this disc brings
consistently more conceptual songs
tracks like he-man and welfare and rap
dope and child support all really decent
tracks if you don't like this album thus
far stick around for the second disc it
definitely does pick up and if you do
like this album well you're in for a
treat but still in my opinion the second
disc of this album still suffer from
most of the issues that plagued the
first disc a little filler here and
there a few features to many the
recording quality really destroying the
momentum of these songs still there were
shining moments on this record though
where I thought blue was delivering some
of his best material and in a sense I
did get an ambitious project and even
with some of the tracks that I thought
were just okay I was imagining myself in
an alternate universe where the song was
actually
chorded really well and it sounded
pretty good there at the end of the day
while there are a lot of qualities on
this album that I like this help he just
left so much to be desired in terms of
just execution I'm feeling a light six
on this thing transition if you've given
this record to listen what did you think
of it did you love it did you hate it
why what do you think I should review
next and that's it
Anthony Fantan Oh blue forever
